detail_description: Petra Night Restaurant is a must-visit spot in the ancient city of Petra, located in the south of Jordan. The restaurant offers a traditional menu featuring an abundance of meat and mezze, all fresh and locally sourced. Guests can enjoy a unique dining experience with separate areas for smokers and non-smokers, which is uncommon in Jordan. The ambiance is enhanced by the eccentric Bedouin hosts who entertain visitors with stories while serving fire-cooked meals.
name: Petra Night Restaurant

detail_description: For over 700 years, Petra remained a hidden and secret city, known only to the Bedouins and Arab traders. It was often referred to as the Lost City due to its obscurity. Despite its historical significance, it vanished from Western awareness after the 14th century AD.
name: Little Petra Restaurant
address: بالقرب من مركز الزوار, Tourism St, Wadi Musa 71810, Jordan

excerpt: Wadi Musa is a town located in the Ma'an Governorate in southern Jordan. It is the administrative center of the Petra Department and the nearest town to the archaeological site of Petra, being only 3.5 km away. Most of the locals belong to the Liyathnah tribe. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Wadi Musa, situated in the Ma'an Governorate of southern Jordan, is a town that serves as the administrative center of the Petra Department. It is located just 3.5 km away from the renowned archaeological site of Petra and is predominantly inhabited by members of the Liyathnah tribe. The town attracts around half a million visitors annually who come to explore the ancient wonders such as Byzantine mosaics, Nabatean crypts, and historic temples in Petra.
name: Wadi Musa

detail_description: Experience the ultimate finale to your Petra adventure with a visit to The Cave Bar. Located just outside the park gates at Petra Guest House, this 2,000-year-old cave bar offers a unique setting for unwinding after exploring the ancient city. Enjoy drinks and shisha in an atmosphere steeped in history, as it is built within an ancient tomb that was once part of Petra. Despite slightly higher drink prices, the ambiance and historical significance make it a must-visit spot.
name: The Cave Bar

excerpt: Tickets, guides & information are available at this visitor center in Petra Archaeological Park.
detail_description: The Petra Visitor Center is the starting point for exploring the main archaeological site of Petra. Visitors can obtain tickets, guides, and information here before embarking on a guided tour through the ancient city. The tour includes a walk through little Petra back roads, viewing ancient agricultural facilities and water basins. A lunch break in front of the Monastery offers stunning views, followed by exploration of the colonnaded cardo, temples, royal facades, theater, and the famous treasury.
name: Petra Visitor Center

detail_description: When visiting Petra, make sure to stop by the Petra Museum located near the archaeological site's entrance. Here, you can delve into the history, culture, and art of Petra and the Nabateans through a collection of artifacts, sculptures, inscriptions, and models. The museum offers interactive displays and multimedia presentations that provide insights into the life and achievements of this ancient civilization. Additionally, guided tours are available to enrich your understanding of Petra's rich heritage.
name: Petra Museum

detail_description: At Petra Kitchen, visitors can immerse themselves in the Jordanian culinary tradition by participating in nightly cooking classes and dinners. The communal atmosphere allows guests to work alongside local chefs to prepare authentic dishes using fresh, local ingredients. This experience not only provides an opportunity to learn traditional recipes but also serves as a way for the people of Petra to share their history and culture with visitors.
name: Petra Kitchen
address: Boutique hotel, Tourism St at, Wadi Musa 71810, Jordan

detail_description: Red Cave Restaurant is a traditional Jordanian eatery located in a cave on Tourism Street, just a short walk from the Visitor Center and many hotels. The restaurant offers a friendly atmosphere and serves local Bedouin specialties such as mensaf and makloubeh. It's known for its traditional Arabic feast and vegetarian options.
name: Red Cave Restaurant

detail_description: Al Yakhor Turkish Bath is a must-visit in Petra for a traditional and rejuvenating experience. After a day of sightseeing, immerse yourself in the soothing warmth of the steam room before indulging in an invigorating body scrub and massage by skilled masseuses. The ambiance is welcoming, with a lovely lobby offering hot mint tea upon arrival. The service includes convenient arrangements such as car pick-up, making it easy to unwind after exploring Petra.
name: al yakhor turkish bath
address: Al Yakhor Turkish bath, Wadi Musa, Jordan

detail_description: Petra, a renowned historical site, offers the iconic Petra Monastery trail, which is a must-see for visitors. The 45-minute walk to the Monastery provides breathtaking views and is just the beginning of what Petra has to offer. Exploring this massive site can take several days, with popular spots like The Treasury and the Monastery connected by a challenging 3-mile hike.
name: Petra

detail_description: "My Mom's Recipe Restaurant" is a charming eatery that offers a modern twist on traditional Jordanian cuisine. The restaurant provides lunch and dinner buffets featuring an array of local dishes, including Mansaf, Galaya, Moussaka, lamb chops, shish kebab, grilled chicken, various soups, hummus, tabooleh, green salad, baba ganouj, baklava and harees.
name: My Mom's Recipe Restaurant
address: Tourism Street, Petra - Wadi Musa, Wadi Musa, Jordan

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Wadi Musa, The Aloe Vera Restaurant is a delightful culinary gem that showcases the rich flavors of Jordanian cuisine. This charming eatery is not just about food; it’s an experience steeped in warm hospitality and attentive service. Guests rave about their visits, highlighting how staff members like Omar and Deaa go above and beyond to ensure every need is met, from accommodating dietary restrictions to providing friendly recommendations.
name: The Aloe Vera Restaurant
address: Petra , Main Tourist Street, Wadi Musa 71810, Jordan

detail_description: The Djinn Blocks in Petra, Jordan are named after a belief that spirits inhabit them, but they have actually served as tombs or memorials for the dead. These cubical monuments, including numbers 7, 8 and 9 out of the total 25 blocks present there, may have been used for carving practice or as boundary markers. The historical landmark is located in a mountainous area with many caves and houses within a short distance from the main gate.
name: Djinn Blocks

detail_description: Go Jordan Travel and Tourism offers fantastic tours of Jordan, allowing visitors to experience the country's diverse attractions. While a 4-day tour may feel a bit rushed due to the extensive sights, it still ensures sufficient time at each location. The agency is praised for its personalized service, competitive pricing, and flexibility in accommodating changing needs. One traveler highlighted their amazing experience on a 6-day trip with Go Jordan, feeling like part of the family throughout the journey.
name: Go Jordan Travel and Tourism

detail_description: Exploring Jordanian local food is an adventure that tantalizes the taste buds and warms the heart. During my recent culinary journey, I was fortunate to have knowledgeable neighbors who guided me through both language and culture. One memorable experience took place at a charming restaurant where the ambiance instantly transported me to Jordan with its authentic decor and welcoming atmosphere. The staff were incredibly friendly, showcasing their expertise in traditional dishes.
name: Jordanian local food

excerpt: Rock-carved temple featuring an elaborate facade & believed to have been a mausoleum.
detail_description: The Treasury, also known as the rock-carved temple, is a remarkable site located in Petra, Jordan. This elaborate facade is believed to have been a mausoleum for the Nabataean King Aretas III around 100 BCE to 200 CE. The Hellenistic craftsmanship of the Treasury's facade is truly astonishing and has captivated visitors for centuries. It has gained international fame, particularly due to its appearance in the Indiana Jones movie "The Last Crusade.
name: The Treasury

excerpt: Venerable rock monastery & spiritual site constructed in 3 B.C. as a monumental Nabataean tomb.
detail_description: The Monastery, also known as Ad Deir, is a remarkable rock monastery and spiritual site that dates back to 3 B.C. It is a monumental Nabataean tomb located in Petra. The hike to reach the Monastery is quite challenging but definitely worth it for the breathtaking view it offers. The facade of the Monastery, carved into the sandstone mountain, leaves visitors speechless with its grandeur.
name: Ad-Dayr

excerpt: Classical style Nabataean period tomb frontage carved into the sandstone at Siq al-Barid canyon.
detail_description: Triclinium, located in the Siq al-Barid canyon, features a classical style Nabataean period tomb frontage carved into sandstone. The site includes a 400m-long path leading to open areas with a temple and four triclinia, likely used as dining rooms for merchants and travelers. Visitors can explore this less popular trail from Little Petra, which takes about 3.5 hours to hike.
name: Triclinium

excerpt: Series of mausoleums with impressive facades hewn from the face of the Jabal al-Khubtha massif.
detail_description: The Royal Tombs in Petra are a collection of grand mausoleums carved into the cliffs of Jabal al-Khubtha. These impressive burial places, also known as the biggest and most remarkable tombs in Petra, exhibit stunning architecture and craftsmanship from the ancient Nabatean civilization. The facades of these tombs, which were likely constructed for Nabatean royalty and high-ranking individuals, feature a blend of Nabatean, Hellenistic, and Roman design elements.
name: Royal Tombs

excerpt: Part of the sprawling Petra complex, these temple remains feature floral reliefs & ruins of columns.
detail_description: Qasr al-Bint is a significant part of the Petra complex, featuring temple remains with floral reliefs and columns. Visitors can explore other nearby attractions such as The Monastery, Temple of Dushares, and Renaissance Tomb. The area also offers opportunities to observe archaeologists at work preserving the ruins. Additionally, there are old Nabatean baths, a museum, and a restaurant for visitors to enjoy.
name: Qasr al-Bint

detail_description: Mousa's Spring, also known as Ain Musa, is a historical site situated in Wadi Musa, Jordan. The spring is housed within a distinctive building near the town's exit and has been providing drinking water to people for millennia. While there are no entry fees and it's not usually crowded, some visitors hope for better maintenance to enhance the overall experience. The cold and refreshing spring water has been tested and confirmed as drinkable with rich mineral content.
name: Mousa's Spring

excerpt: Ancient burial chamber & Byzantine church carved out of sandstone cliffs, with a colonnaded terrace.
detail_description: The Urn Tomb is an ancient burial chamber and Byzantine church carved into sandstone cliffs in Petra, Jordan. It is one of the Royal Tombs, featuring a distinctive enormous urn on top of the pediment. This tomb was built around AD 70 for King Malichos II or Aretas IV and has a vast interior measuring 18m by 20m with naturally patterned walls.
name: Urn Tomb

detail_description: The Corinthian tomb stands out among others due to its slight Roman influence, making it unique and magnificent. Inside the tomb, the exposed carved rock displays bands of extraordinary colors that create a surreal atmosphere. Although located slightly ahead of the Royal tombs, it is definitely worth visiting. The upper part of this tomb bears resemblance to the Treasury but has suffered erosion over time. This architectural masterpiece combines elements from both Nabataean and classical styles.
name: Corinthian tomb
Ed-Deir Trail
address: 8CPP+FG9, The Monastery Rte, Uum Sayhoun, Jordan

excerpt: Natural passage leading visitors through red-rock walls on the way to temples & other sites.
detail_description: Al-Siq, a 1.2km narrow canyon in Petra, Jordan, is a mesmerizing natural passage leading visitors through red-rock walls towards the hidden city. This magical corridor holds spiritual significance and offers an unforgettable experience as it snakes its way to the ancient city. Walking through Al-Siq feels like stepping back in time, surrounded by history and impressive rock formations. The anticipation builds with every turn, as visitors eagerly await the breathtaking view of the Treasury at Petra.
name: Al-Siq

excerpt: Set atop a mountain, this Nabatean sacrificial altar offers spectacular views of ancient Petra.
detail_description: The High Place of Sacrifice is a Nabatean altar located atop a mountain with stunning views of ancient Petra. The trail to the site begins near the Theater and requires ascending several steps, but visitors can also opt for a donkey ride. The area boasts beautiful surroundings, making it a satisfying spot to rest after the climb. While sacrifices are no longer conducted at this historical landmark, it remains an enjoyable destination for tourists.
name: High Place of Sacrifice

detail_description: The exquisite Broken Pediment Tomb, an impressive historical monument, showcases remarkable architectural beauty. This landmark holds immense significance as a symbol of the past. With its stunning design and intricate details, this structure is undoubtedly a sight to behold. Its classic broken pediment style adds elegance and grandeur to its overall appearance. Serving as a testament to history's depth and cultural richness, the Broken Pediment Tomb stands tall as a timeless masterpiece that captivates all who lay eyes upon it.
name: Broken Pediment Tomb

excerpt: Iconic 2000-year-old city, including 45m-high Al Khazneh, carved into the red mountain rock.
detail_description: Petra is an iconic 2000-year-old city in Jordan, featuring the impressive 45m-high Al Khazneh carved into the red mountain rock. Built by the Nabataeans in the 3rd century BC, this sandstone city is a World Heritage Site and a must-see destination in Jordan. Visitors typically spend at least two days exploring its palaces, temples, tombs, storerooms, and stables carved from soft stone cliffs.
name: Petra

detail_description: The Renaissance Tomb is a hidden gem in Petra, away from the crowds and touristy areas. It's worth the hike to reach this fascinating location where you can explore a tomb with 14 graves. The atmosphere inside is serene and transports you back thousands of years. The beautiful sandstone colors inside make for great photo opportunities. This spot is part of the Wadi al Farasa Trail, which offers a magnificent and peaceful experience away from the hustle and bustle of more popular sites in Petra.
name: Renaissance Tomb

excerpt: Burial complex carved into rocks around 2,000 years ago, with 4 pyramid-shaped pillars.
detail_description: The Obelisk Tomb is an ancient burial complex that was carved into rocks around 2,000 years ago in Petra. The tomb features four pyramid-shaped pillars and is a genuine Nabataean site with a rich history. It is one of the notable attractions on the way to the "Treasury" and offers visitors a wider view of the area after climbing to its top.
name: Obelisk Tomb & Bab as-Siq Triclinium.

excerpt: Archaeological ruins of a massive structure covering an area of 1 hectare in the city of Petra.
detail_description: The Great Temple is an archaeological wonder located in Petra, covering a vast area of 76,000 sq. ft. Entrance to the site is through a narrow tunnel called Siq, which leads to the red temple carved out of multicolored cliffs. The ruins of ancient city and amphitheater along with dwellings carved out of cliffs offer much to explore in this historical landmark that has stood the test of time.
name: Great Temple

detail_description: Nestled within the enchanting landscape of Little Petra, "The Painted House" is a hidden gem that beckons travelers to explore its captivating artistry. This charming site features intricate frescoes on its ceilings, showcasing detailed depictions of birds and trees that transport you back in time to the heart of Nabataean culture.
name: The Painted House
